awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Teacher Research Teams II: Expanding Pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, the University of Colorado at Boulder (CU-Boulder) will partner with Front Range Community College, (FRCC, Boulder County campus). This Scholarships & Stipends Phase II project, Collaborative Research: Teacher Research Teams II: Expanding Pathways, will support up to 36 juniors/seniors/post-baccalaureate students who are majoring in mathematics, a science discipline, or engineering (or who have completed such a major), and who are preparing to teach secondary mathematics or science in a high-need district. Approximately 40% of the scholarship funds will be awarded to undergraduates who transfer to CU-Boulder from FRCC. Each Noyce Scholar will receive 1 or 2 years of scholarship support. Project activities include a Learning Assistant (LA) program, in which faculty members engage with selected undergraduates to think about how they might improve the experience and outcomes for enrolled students, and Teacher Research Team (TRT) experiences, in which prospective teachers (Noyce Scholars), experienced and novice teachers, teacher educators, and prospective teacher educators (education graduate students) discuss and plan research, practice, assessment, and curriculum.

Building on prior work, the project will (a) develop a LA program at FRCC, which will provide early teaching opportunities to two-year college STEM students; (b) expand the Noyce Scholarship program to include FRCC students who transfer to CU-Boulder; and (c) leverage the TRT experience as a mechanism for teacher preparation, novice teacher induction, and professional development of teachers. Research focused on the two-year to four-year college pathway will address the following questions: (1) To what extent does having an LA experience at FRCC increase transfer to CU-Boulder and completion of a STEM degree at CU-Boulder? What factors of the FRCC LA program influence students' decisions to transfer to and complete a STEM degree at CU-Boulder? (2) After students transfer to CU-Boulder, to what extent does participating in another LA experience or TRT lead to enrollment and completion in the CU-Teach licensure program? What factors of these experiences at CU-Boulder influence students' decisions to pursue K-12 STEM teaching?

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Outcome 1:  Twenty-eight (28) of the 33 total recruited Noyce scholars and fellows are currently teaching math and/or science in middle schools and high schools, serving an estimated 3,200 students per year. 

This project provided Noyce scholarship and stipend support to 16 undergraduate students and 17 post-BA students in their final stages of completing their licensure to teach K-12 math and/or science in Colorado. Of these individuals, 28 are currently teaching in high-needs school districts. Nine  participants of this project have fulfilled their teaching obligations and most have continued to teach beyond their commitment. Among the 9 teachers who have fulfilled their obligation, the average teaching commitment was 1.8 years, however, this cohort has taught an average of 2.6 years (so far). Nineteen additional teachers are progressing towards their teaching commitments, with an average commitment of 2.7 years. Three recent licensure recipients are seeking teaching positions, and one student is completing their licensure. One of the 33 recipients, one left the program and is required to repay the scholarship.

 

Outcome 2: Developed an induction model for recent Noyce graduates who have been teaching for 0-4 years. The Noyce Scholar / Noyce Induction Teacher (NIT) program provided a valuable community for early career teachers and those getting ready to enter the profession. 

The goals of the Noyce/NIT program were to (1) Provide authentic, professional systems of support for prospective and practicing teachers through targeted mentoring in a professional STEM educator community, (2) Engage prospective and practicing teachers in activities that professionalize the challenges and opportunities that they face in their teaching experiences and coursework through reflective activities such as problems of practice, content-specific lesson workshops, and needs-based professional development, and (3) Engage prospective and practicing teachers in activities and discussions that keeps Culturally and Linguistically Responsive Teaching (CLRT) and Social Emotional Learning (SEL) at the forefront. The Noyce/NIT group was led by two former Noyce Master Teaching Fellows, and in the final year of the project, four Noyce Scholars and 20 Noyce Induction Teachers (NITs) participated in the community. 

 The Noyce/NIT program features were refined each year based on feedback from Noyce Scholars and Noyce Induction Teachers as well as data from project evaluators. In the 2021/22 school year, Noyce Scholars and Noyce Induction Teachers participated in 10 face-to- face meetings that were co-constructed with Scholars/NITs. The meetings were divided into three 30-min sections beginning with the Problem of Practice activity, followed by a Community Building Activity, and then finishing with Content-Specific (math and science) work sessions. Topics For the Community Building activity included discussions of the book "Phenomenal Teaching", sharing successes and challenges from the classroom, writing and sharing purpose statements, discussions in support of increased student engagement, and networking and sharing information about job opportunities. Topics for the content-specific work sessions included alignment of math and science standards, assessment design, general classroom management and structures, and sharing and reviewing effective technology resources. In previous years, Noyce Scholars and NITs met separately for the first half of the meeting and then together for the second half. It became increasingly clear that both the Noyce Scholars and the NITs were benefiting from the larger group meeting. Therefore, in the final year of the project all of the meeting time was with combined groups.

Outcome 3: Collaborated with Front Range Community College-Boulder County Campus (FRCC-BCC) to establish a Learning Assistant (LA) program as a pathway for two-year students to transfer and complete their Bachelor's degree in a STEM discipline at University of Colorado Boulder. 

One goal of this project was to (a) Develop a Learning Assistant program at Front Range Community College (FRCC), (b) including an online version of the LA pedagogy course, and (c) test its efficacy as a mechanism for two-year college students to transfer to CU Boulder, (d) complete their degree in a STEM discipline, and (e) enroll in and complete the CU- Teach math and science teaching licensure program.

We were successful in goals a-d. The online version of the LA pedagogy course continues to provide broader access to students who want to participate in the LA program. A total of 52 FRCC students served as Learning Assistants, and 22 (42%) of students who served as FRCC Learning Assistants transferred to CU Boulder.

Of the students who transferred, eight had completed their bachelor's degrees as of May 2022. They earned degrees in Computer Science (1), Mathematics (2), Chemical & Biological Engineering (1), Engineering Physics (1), Biochemistry (1), and Astronomy (2). The other students who transferred are still working towards completing their Bachelor's degree at CU Boulder. None of these students were successfully recruited into teaching, so goal (e) was ummet.

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Laurie S Langdon
